sen.e: "Takasago" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

sen.j: 相生の松によせて夫婦愛と長寿を愛で、人世を言祝ぐ大変めでたい能である。
sen.e: It is a very joyous Noh piece that cherishes matrimonial love and long life, and congratulates a life, relating both to Aioi no Matsu (twin pines: Japanese red pine and Japanese black pine that share a root).

It is a very joyous Noh piece that cherishes matrimonial love and long life and celebrates life itself, relating both to Aioi no Matsu (twin pines: Japanese red pine and Japanese black pine that share their roots).
sen.cmt: コンマを削除しました。Congratulates a lifeをcelebrates life itselfにしました。A rootをtheir rootsにしました。
sen.e: It is a very joyous Noh piece that cherishes matrimonial love and long life and celebrates life itself, relating both to Aioi no Matsu (twin pines: Japanese red pine and Japanese black pine that share their roots).

sen.j: ワキ、ワキヅレがアイとの問答の後、上ゲ謌で謡う『高砂や、この浦舟に帆を上げて、この浦舟に帆を上げて、月もろともに出で潮の、波の淡路の島影や、遠く鳴尾の沖過ぎて、はや住吉（すみのえ）に着きにけり、はや住吉に着きにけり』は結婚披露宴の定番の一つである。
sen.e: A ageuta (A segment of sung, metered poetry beginning in the upper register), "Takasagoya (Hallelujah!), hoisting a sail to a floating boat on this creek, on the rising tide coming with the moon, through surfs on the lee of islands of Awaji, passing by the distant coast of Naruo, already I reach to Suminoe, already I reach to Suminoe", which is intoned after ai (the role of a kyogen actor in Noh) hold a dialogue with Waki (supporting actor) and Wakitsure (companion who appears with the supporting actor in a Noh play), is a typical piece performed at a wedding celebration party.

The following ageuta (segment of sung, metered poetry beginning in the upper register) that is sung by the priest and his companion after the dialogue with the ai (role of the Noh kyogen actor) is one of the standards performed at wedding receptions: "Takasagoya (Hallelujah!), hoist the sail on this boat, hoist the sail on this boat, on the rising tide coming with the moon, through surfs on the lee of islands of Awaji, passing by the distant coast of Naruo, already I reach Suminoe, already I reach Suminoe."
sen.cmt: 順序を変えました。冠詞を修正しました。作品の理解に必要ない日本語の単語を一般英語に変えました。
sen.e: The following ageuta (segment of sung, metered poetry beginning in the upper register) that is sung by the priest and his companion after the dialogue with the ai (role of the Noh kyogen actor) is one of the standards performed at wedding receptions: "Takasagoya (Hallelujah!), hoist the sail on this boat, hoist the sail on this boat, on the rising tide coming with the moon, through surfs on the lee of islands of Awaji, passing by the distant coast of Naruo, already I reach Suminoe, already I reach Suminoe."

sen.j: 九州阿蘇宮の神官（ワキ）が播磨の国、高砂の浦にやってきた。
sen.e: Shinto priest of Kyushu Aso no miya Shrine (waki) comes to creek of Takasago, in Harima Province.
A Shinto priest (supporting role) from Aso no miya Shrine in Kyushu has come to an inlet in Takasago, Harima Province.
sen.cmt: 神宮、場所の順序を変えました。Ofをfromに変えました。Wakiをsupporting roleにしました。Creekをinletに変えました。
sen.e: A Shinto priest (supporting role) from Aso no miya Shrine in Kyushu has come to an inlet in Takasago, Harima Province.

sen.j: 春風駘蕩とする浦には松が美しい。
sen.e: There is a beautiful pine tree at the creek, and the mild spring breeze is blowing.
The pine standing at the inlet amid the mild spring breeze is beautiful.
sen.cmt: 原文により忠実にしました。
sen.e: The pine standing at the inlet amid the mild spring breeze is beautiful.

sen.j: 遠く鐘の音も聞こえる。
sen.e: The sound of bells from afar can be heard.
The sound of bells from afar can be heard.

sen.j: そこに老夫婦（シテとツレ）が来て、木陰を掃き清める。
sen.e: An elderly couple (shite and tsure) comes by and starts to sweep the shade of the tree clean.
An elderly couple (main and secondary roles) come and start to sweep under the shade of the tree.
sen.cmt: 動詞を修正しました（coupleは複数）。
sen.e: An elderly couple (main and secondary roles) come and start to sweep under the shade of the tree.

sen.j: 老人は古今和歌集の仮名序を引用して、高砂の松と住吉の松とは相生の松、離れていても夫婦であるとの伝説を説き、松の永遠、夫婦相老（相生にかけている）の仲睦まじさを述べる。
sen.e: The old man preaches the legend that pine tree in Takasago and pine tree in Suminoe are the Aioi no Matsu and they are a husband and wife even though they are far apart, quoting from Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (Preface of Kokinwakashu written in kana by KI no Tsurayuki), and speaks eternity of pine tree and harmoniousness of fufu-aioi (fufu (husband and wife) living a long life together; that plays on word 'aioi(相老: become old together)' and 'aioi (相生: live together)').

The old man, quoting from Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (preface of Kokin Wakashu written in kana by KI no Tsurayuki), preaches that the pine tree in Takasago and one in Suminoe are Aioi no Matsu (pines sharing a life), that they are a husband and wife even though they are far apart, and speaks of the eternity of pine trees and harmoniousness of spousal-aioi (play on word 'aioi' – the first to share a life, and the second to become old together).
sen.cmt: 読みやすくするため、括弧の使用を少なくなるよう修正しました。
sen.e: The old man, quoting from Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (preface of Kokin Wakashu written in kana by KI no Tsurayuki), preaches that the pine tree in Takasago and one in Suminoe are Aioi no Matsu (pines sharing a life), that they are a husband and wife even though they are far apart, and speaks of the eternity of pine trees and harmoniousness of spousal-aioi (play on word 'aioi' – the first to share a life, and the second to become old together).

sen.j: 命あるものは全て、いや自然の全ては和歌の道に心を寄せるという。
sen.e: Implying that all the living things, no, all natures give their heart to way of waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables).
They say all living things, and in fact, all things in nature are attracted to the way of waka (traditional poems of thirty-one syllables).
They say all living things, and in fact, all things in nature are attracted to the way of waka (traditional poems of thirty-one syllables).

sen.j: ここで老夫婦は自分達は高砂・住吉の松の精である事を打ち明け、小舟に乗り追風をはらんで消えて行く。
sen.e: Here the elderly couple reveals that they are spirits of pine trees in Takasago and Suminoe, and on a boat, they disappear with a tailwind.
Here the elderly couple reveal that they are spirits of pine trees in Takasago and Suminoe, and they get on a small boat and disappear, their sail filled with the tailwind.
sen.cmt: 動詞を修正しました（coupleは複数）。後部を意訳しました。
sen.e: Here the elderly couple reveal that they are spirits of pine trees in Takasago and Suminoe, and they get on a small boat and disappear, their sail filled with the tailwind.

sen.j: 神官もまた満潮に乗って舟を出し（ここで『高砂や...』となる）、松の精を追って住吉に辿り着く。
sen.e: Shinto priest also set sail on high tide (here intones "Takasagoya..") and arrives at Suminoe following spirits of pine trees.
The priest also sets sail on the high tide (here the famous lines "Takasagoya..." are sung), and arrives at Suminoe after the spirits of the pine trees.
sen.cmt: 冠詞を追加しました。時制を修正しました。括弧内の説明を修正しました。
sen.e: The priest also sets sail on the high tide (here the famous lines "Takasagoya..." are sung), and arrives at Suminoe after the spirits of the pine trees.

sen.j: 『われ見ても 久しくなりぬ住吉の、岸の姫松いく代経ぬらん』（伊勢物語）の歌に返して、なんと住吉明神の御本体が影向（ようごう）され、美しい月光の下、颯爽と神舞を舞う。
sen.e: Answering to a poem "long times has passed, even from my point of view, how many generations the small pine tree on the bank of Suminoe has spent" (Ise Monogatari(The tales of Ise)), the deity of Sumiyoshi Myojin appears in an assumed form and gallantly dances Kami mai under the beautiful moonlight.

Answering the poem "A long time has passed, even from my perspective; how many generations has that princess pine on the banks of Suminoe been" (Ise Monogatari [The Tales of Ise]), the deity of Sumiyoshi Myojin appears in an assumed form and gallantly dances the Kami mai (god dance) under the beautiful moonlight.
sen.cmt: 冠詞を追加しました。詩を少し修正しました。Talesを大文字にしました。神舞の説明を追加しました。
sen.e: Answering the poem "A long time has passed, even from my perspective; how many generations has that princess pine on the banks of Suminoe been" (Ise Monogatari [The Tales of Ise]), the deity of Sumiyoshi Myojin appears in an assumed form and gallantly dances the Kami mai (god dance) under the beautiful moonlight.

sen.j: 『千秋楽は民を撫で、萬歳楽には命を延ぶ、相生の松風、颯々の聲ぞ楽しむ、颯々の聲ぞ楽しむ』（トメ拍子）。
sen.e: "Make the people glad with the joy of a Thousand Autumns, dance of manzairaku (an auspicious dance and song wishing the sovereign Ten Thousand Years) extend life of emperor, how joyous the sound of breeze from Aioi no Matsu, how joyous the gallant singing voice of the god" (tome-hyoshi (closing stamps)).

"The music of a thousand autumns soothes the people, the music of ten thousand years extends life; the breeze of the Aioi pines, how joyous the sound of the breeze, how joyous the sound of the breeze" (tome-hyoshi [closing stamps]).
